Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with this course compared to others you have taken was
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
How would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other F&ES courses you have taken?
Given the course objectives, the level of intellectual challenge of the material covered was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
How well did the knowledge, skills, and insights gained in this class align with your expectations
What are the strengths and weaknesses of the course and how could it be improved?
What advice would you give to a student considering taking this class
Comments_List: Unfortunately this class did not add much if you have taken most FES energy classes or worked in the sector before school. I did enjoy some of the deeper dives on certain policies but the course was such a broad overview of many different topics that didn't efficiently take advantage of the immense experience of the professor or guest speakers.
It was fascinating to receive such an insiders view of the Obama Administration's energy policy.

I came in with very little knowledge of current energy policy and left feeling as though I have a strong foundation from which to work from. The speakers and Dan are all leaders in energy policy, so more than most classes, the material felt current and up to date.

Writing concise memo's
Knowledge of an array of energy topics
First hand insights from senior ex White House officials

I'm really interested in policy, so perhaps my review would be more biased. The class was really interesting though and improved I think as Dan moved further along during the semester. The guest speakers were excellent and really brought a broad range of perspectives.
I learned about policymaking considerations from a non-legal perspective.
History of U.S. and global environmental policy. What has worked and why..
I learned about energy policy and climate policy.

I learned so much about so many parts of the energy sector (and GHG policy) from so many perspectives that it's difficult to distill them into a single paragraph. However, I think that was the value of the course: exposure to the myriad energy/climate policy issues and the regulatory tools we have to address them.

gained an understanding of climate and energy policy at the federal and state level, framework for successful policy advocacy, political landscape and intricacies of passing effective bi-partisan legislation in the current political climate
This class was a great first dive into policy issues. I felt like we covered a lot of ground without sacrificing quality.
Very little.
Great speakers and interesting perspectives from practitioners.

This course was a great overview of federal energy policymaking in the US. It was interesting to take a class from a true practitioner. I also enjoyed the weekly guest speakers and felt that they contributed a lot to the overall class experience.
Got to dig more into policy topics I didn't have much context in previously.

This course was very useful and applicable to real work in energy policy in the United States. I learned very useful background information on all forms of U.S. energy policy that I will certainly use in the coming years.
How to understand and analyze different types of federal energy policies.
Dan did a great job at introducing us to as many energy policy topics as possible. It gave me a whole new insight into the energy sector.

This course was a great overview of the energy policy space in the US. It gave a good background on the historical evolution of US energy policy as well as went into detail on Obama-era policies. 

I also developed better memo writing skills through the written assignments and the feedback on the memos was really helpful.
Very well. My favorite thing about the course was how the professor tried to simulate real world meetings and memos with the papers. It made the assignments much more interesting to complete.

Largely in line with what I wanted to learn. I would say that some of the assignments didn't really line up with the practical, real-world structure of the class - they felt very hypothetical in nature and largely just exercises in memo writing rather than creative policymaking.
Very well, I got what i expected and more
Yep! It's really interesting. I really liked the topics that Dan chose to focus on and some of the readings.
Very well.
Aligned very well with my expectations.
Very well, to the extent that I had expectations. There were so many aspects of this course that were new to me that I wasn't sure exactly what I would learn, but I found it all valuable.
Pretty much on point with my expectation
This course exceeded my expectations. I was particularly happy with the rich conversations we had with the guest speakers.
Reasonably well. Would have liked more engaging lectures.
The class aligned well with my expectations.
Yes, speakers were great. Dan's insights were best when off the cuff.
They aligned very well with my expectations.
Pretty well.
I gained more knowledge than I was expecting. Dan laid out the material very well, making it easy to learn.
I did not have many concrete expectations on this class as it was newly offered, but overall I gained a lot of knowledge on energy policy and I am glad I took the class.

The class should really narrow its focus so it can dive deeper into more topics rather than skim the surface on many. I would have also appreciated a quantitative component, even just learning how to do a cost benefit analysis or learn about the regulatory impact analysis for federal regulations. This would have helped my understanding of how to assess policies and is more realistic in how policies are actually made.

Strengths are the guest speakers and creative assignment formats. Weakness is the lecture style which started off as a bit unengaging but it seemed to improve throughout the semester, with more student discussions worked into the slides.

The readings and topics covered were great, but to be honest, the lectures were really difficult to get through. It was clear that everyone that spoke to us was a practitioner and not an educator - which isn't always a bad thing - but really made for quite dry class periods. If I'm going to be honest, once you got past the impressive resumes of the speakers, everything else was a bit of a let-down. I also felt as though there was a lack of diversity amongst the speakers. Everyone who spoke felt very much like an insider, with little critique from outside voices who might be affected by energy policy at the community-level. I know this is a bit of a shift in what the intention of the class is, but I do find it hard to believe that only one person of color could be brought in, and that no one from outside the Beltway was given a platform to speak. 

I also think this course likely should do away with the memo writing exercises and instead provide students an opportunity to really dive deep on an area of energy policy that applies to their work.

Dan used a lot of power point, which is fine, but some of the later presentations were just more interesting in terms of how they were formatted. Thinking about which decks were the best received and told a story as opposed to just gave information I think would be helpful.

The alternative classes were also pretty helpful (i.e. the cabinet meeting). I had worked in politics, so the impact on me might not have been as much but I think it would be cool for others to have more of those experiences.

A little more guided feedback on the memos could be helpful too.
It would have helped to have a little more introductory material for the subjects covered.

Strengths include the professor teaching from his experience and giving insight into the political process of environmental policy. 

The class wasn't quite as strong when it relied on powerpoints.

The strengths were the guest lecturers, the in-class exercises, and the outstanding syllabus Professor Utech assembled, which is like a brain-trust on energy policy. 

The weakness was in Professor Utech's lecturing style. The students were very interested in the course topic, but unfortunately the lecture style stymied discussion and the professor oftentimes missed student questions. 

I believe we would have learned more if the professor discussed the topics, rather than reading from a pre-written lecture. He has a wealth of knowledge and experience, but unfortunately, the execution was lacking. Also, the class ppt slides were extremely text-heavy.

I appreciated having Dan introduce us to a topic each week, then hearing from someone currently working in that space for the second class meeting. I found that extremely effective for prepping us for an in-depth lecture/conversation with the guest lecturer.
The incorporation of speakers and the variety in their topics was outstanding. The lecture portion was sometimes dry and often a repetition of the reading material but I enjoyed in nonetheless.
The guest speakers added great, diverse perspectives and excellent expertise. Dan was not a strong lecturer, but he improved through out the course and overall I enjoyed his lectures.
The speakers were the highlight. Normal lectures were difficult to sit through due to the monotone and monotonous nature of the presentations

Guest speakers were great.

Lectures were better towards the end, but still need to be more engaging.

I really enjoyed the class structure with guest speakers and also thought the assignments and readings were very good. I thought it might have been better to structure the class with less lecture and more classroom discussion. I really enjoyed the classes where we broke into groups.
Less text on slides. :)
I really enjoyed the guest speaker portion of this class and thought it was incredibly useful to hear real perspectives. As I said, I think the assignments were very useful as well.
Strengths were the guest speakers and Dan's variety in topics covered. No big weaknesses.
The guest lectures made the class. They added another depth to class that made it more engaging.
The guest speakers were phenomenal! The readings were well thought through and the lectures were pretty good at covering a lot of material. I enjoyed this class.

Always do the readings (including the recommended readings) and come prepared with questions. When Dan was asked about things in the readings he was much more open and relaxed in a way that really promoted dialogue amongst the class.

Take this course if you'd like to learn more about energy/climate change in a more substantive way. If you're not new to energy you may learn a little less but the insights from Dan and other ex white house officials makes this course worth taking.

It's a really good broad overview of policy, with excellent speakers. I'd say don't take it if you aren't interested in policy or energy. If you check one of those boxes, you should learn about this space.
Dan is a great practitioner to learn from.
Do the reading! The syllabus is amazing.
Ask as many questions as you can to Dan and the guest lecturersit's an amazing opportunity to access such great knowledge!
Dan has a wealth of knowledge on energy policy and his class is a must take for energy geeks!
Don't
I would absolutely recommend this course to a fellow student considering a future in policy, or even a student who needs a solid policy background. Very useful course.

A lot of the learning from this course comes from the readings - without a strong understanding of the material from the readings, the lectures and guest speakers were less useful. Come prepared for class and the material becomes much more engaging.
